content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

This is a low-power view of a cross-section of the colon. I can identify the layers of the bowel wall: the mucosa at the top, followed by the submucosa, muscularis propria, and the outer layer of adipose tissue. There is a large, ulcerated, and deeply infiltrative tumor occupying the left and central parts of the image, extending from the mucosa into the deeper layers. The normal colonic architecture is effaced by this process. I do not see any distinct lymph nodes in this particular section; it appears to be a representative slice of the primary tumor itself.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it represents the deep invasive front of the tumor. To determine the pathological T stage, it is crucial to assess the maximum depth of tumor invasion. This specific location appears to be at the interface between the bulk of the tumor and the submucosa or muscularis propria. By examining this area at high power, I can confirm the malignant nature of the infiltrating cells, characterize the pattern of invasion, and search for adverse features such as lymphovascular or perineural invasion, which are critical for staging and prognosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I zoomed into this specific area because it represents the deepest point of tumor invasion. Determining the maximum depth of invasion is critical for assigning the correct T stage. This location is at the interface between the main tumor mass and the surrounding pericolic fat. I need to confirm the presence of malignant cells in the adipose tissue to establish a T3 stage and to look for other adverse prognostic features at the invasive front, such as tumor budding, lymphovascular invasion, or perineural invasion. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it represents the main body of the invasive tumor at its interface with the ulcerated surface. This region is critical for several reasons: 1) To confirm the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma and assess its histologic grade (degree of differentiation). 2) To evaluate the morphology of the invasive front. 3) To look for specific features that have prognostic significance, such as mucin production or signet ring cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I zoomed into this specific area because it represents the invasive front of the tumor, which is the deepest point of invasion into the surrounding pericolic fat. Examining this interface is crucial for several reasons: 
1. To definitively determine the pathologic T stage (pT stage) by confirming tumor extension beyond the muscularis propria.
2. To assess for adverse prognostic factors that are often best seen at the invasive front, such as tumor budding, lymphovascular invasion (LVI), and perineural invasion (PNI). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see clear evidence of invasive adenocarcinoma. There are irregular glands and clusters of malignant epithelial cells infiltrating the stroma. The most prominent feature is the presence of large, acellular pools of extracellular mucin. Tumor cells, some forming abortive glands, are seen floating within and at the periphery of these mucin pools. My impression is that this is an invasive adenocarcinoma with prominent mucinous features. The mucin appears to be dissecting through the tissue, a characteristic pattern of invasion for this tumor subtype.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see poorly differentiated, infiltrative adenocarcinoma. There are irregular glands, cords, and single malignant cells invading a desmoplastic stroma. The tumor cells show marked nuclear atypia, with pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and prominent nucleoli. This confirms the presence of invasive carcinoma at the deep margin, extending into the pericolic soft tissue. My impression is that of an aggressive adenocarcinoma, and this finding supports a pathological stage of at least pT3.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. The tumor is composed of irregular, back-to-back, and cribriform glands. The neoplastic cells exhibit marked nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and prominent nucleoli. There is a significant amount of intracellular mucin, visible as clear vacuoles within the cytoplasm of many tumor cells, giving them a signet-ring-like appearance in some areas. The lower portion of the image shows the ulcer bed with hemorrhage and necrotic debris. My impression is that of an invasive, poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with prominent mucinous and potential signet ring cell features, which are generally associated with a poorer prognosis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see poorly formed, irregular glands and nests of malignant epithelial cells infiltrating a desmoplastic stroma. There are significant amounts of extracellular mucin (the pale, acellular material), which is characteristic of a mucinous adenocarcinoma component. The tumor cells exhibit marked nuclear atypia, including pleomorphism and hyperchromasia. My impression is an invasive, moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with prominent mucinous features, confirming deep stromal invasion.
